questions.text: A 42-year-old African American woman presents with visual disturbances. Eye examination reveals vitreous cells, snowball opacities, and candle wax drippings. Which type of uveitis is seen in the underlying disease?
questions.explanation:
Type of Uveitis

Signs

Anterior (Option A)

Granulomatous iridocyclitis, iris nodules, large mutton fat KPs, anterior chamber cells and flare, posterior synechiae

Intermediate

Vitreous cells, snowball opacities, snowbanking

Posterior (Option C)

Choroidal and retinal granulomas, cystoid macular edema, periphlebitis retinae with candle wax droppings appearance

Peripheral Multifocal Chorioretinitis (Option D)

Small, punched-out atrophic spots, highly suggestive of sarcoidosis

Uveoparotid Fever (Heerfordt’s Syndrome)

Bilateral granulomatous panuveitis, painful parotid gland enlargement, cranial nerve palsies, skin rashes, fever, malaise

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with vision loss in his right eye following a traumatic injury that resulted in a penetrating ocular wound two months ago. Recently, he has developed redness, photophobia, and decreased vision in his left eye as well. On examination, both eyes show signs of bilateral granulomatous uveitis. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of the patient's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Type I hypersensitivity reaction to lens proteins

options.label: C
options.text: Direct bacterial infection spreading from the injured eye

options.label: D
options.text: Immune complex deposition in the retinal vasculature

questions.correct_answer: B. Delayed hypersensitivity reaction to melanocytes
questions.explanation:
Sympathetic ophthalmitis (SO)

Definition

Bilateral, granulomatous, panuveitis occurring after penetrating trauma where uveal prolapse may have been a feature of the trauma

Etiology and pathogenesis
  • Trauma to one eye (exciting eye) — 2 weeks to 3 months — Uveitis in the uninjured eye (sympathizing eye).
  • T-cell mediated autoimmune hypersensitivity reaction to Retinal S antigen. (Option B)
  • Maximum risk upon injury to the ciliary body.

Histopathology
  • Diffuse lymphocytic infiltration of the choroid.
  • Scattered aggregates of epithelioid cells are seen, many of which contain fine granules of melanin.
  • Dalen–Fuchs nodules - granulomas located between Bruch membrane and the RPE (also seen in VKH syndrome)

Clinical features
  • The exciting eye is frequently red and irritable.
  • The sympathizing eye develops irritation, blurred vision, photophobia and loss of accommodation causing difficulty in near vision (first symptom)
  • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, which may be mild or severe and is usually granulomatous

Investigations
  • Fundus exam: Dalen–Fuchs nodules, Exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis and optic disc swelling.
  • As inflammation settles, residual chorioretinal scarring may confer a ‘sunset glow’ appearance similar to VKH.
  • B-scan ultrasonography: Choroidal thickening and retinal detachment

Treatment
  • Enucleation of a severely injured eye within 10 to 14 days of the injury is effective in preventing or reducing the severity of SO
  • Steroids are the basis of initial treatment. Intravenous methylprednisolone followed by high-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to response. Supplementary topical steroids and cycloplegics may be given

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman diagnosed with Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) disease, Fundus examination shows the following findings. What does it indicate?
questions.explanation:
Vogt–Koyanagi–Harada (VKH) Syndrome

Definition

Idiopathic multisystem autoimmune disease featuring inflammation of melanocyte-containing tissues such as the uvea, ear, and meninges.

Etiology
  • Idiopathic.
  • HLA associations: HLA-DR1 and HLA-DR4.

Classification
  • Vogt–Koyanagi disease: Skin changes and anterior uveitis.
  • Harada disease: Neurological features and exudative retinal detachments.

Clinical features

Clinically, the disease is categorized into four phases:

  1. Prodromal phase (lasts for a few days): Neurological (meningitis, cranial nerve paresis) and auditory manifestations (tinnitus, vertigo and deafness).
  2. Acute uveitic phase: Bilateral granulomatous anterior and multifocal posterior uveitis with diffuse choroidal infiltration, vitritis, papillitis and exudative retinal detachments. Dalen–Fuchs nodules can be seen in this phase.
  3. Convalescent phase (follows several weeks later): Localized alopecia, poliosis and vitiligo, depigmented fundus appearance (‘sunset glow’ fundus) and depigmented limbal lesions (Sugiura sign). (Option C)
  4. Chronic recurrent phase: smouldering anterior uveitis with exacerbations

Investigations
  • Lumbar puncture: CSF shows a transient lymphocytic pleocytosis and melanin-containing macrophages.
  • Fundus Autofluorescence (FAF): Areas of serous detachment.
  • Ultrasonography: Diffuse choroidal thickening.
  • FA (Fluorescein Angiography) of the acute phase shows multifocal hyperfluorescent dots at the level of the retinal pigment epithelium.
  • OCT: Quantification of subretinal fluid.
  • ICGA: For monitoring

Complications and Prognosis

Ocular complications include:

  • Choroidal neovascularization
  • Subretinal fibrosis
  • Preretinal and disc new vessels
  • Vitreous hemorrhage
  • Cataract
  • Glaucoma

Neurological and auditory manifestations tend to resolve but skin, lash and hair changes usually persist.

Treatment
  • Intravenous methylprednisolone pulse therapy (500–1000 mg/day).
  • High-dose (1–2 mg/kg/day) oral prednisolone, tapered over 3–6 months.
  • Topical steroids and cycloplegics are used for anterior uveitis.
  • Steroid-resistant patients may require immunosuppressives or biological blockers such as infliximab

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with progressively worsening blurry vision, eye pain, and redness in the right eye. Examination reveals restricted eye movement, and fundoscopic evaluation identifies a well-defined cystic lesion in the vitreous humor, accompanied by surrounding inflammation. What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ocular cysticercosis

Definition

Infestation caused by Cysticercus cellulosae, the larval form of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium.

Pathophysiology

Humans ingest eggs of T. solium, leading to larvae formation (cysticercus) in various tissues.

Inflammation is triggered by antigens released from dead larvae, leading to tissue damage.

It is not contracted by eating undercooked pork.

Clinical Features

Systemic Involvement: Larvae can infest the CNS (neurocysticercosis), muscles, lungs, and subcutaneous tissues. Neurological manifestations include seizures and headaches.

Eye involvement:

  • Orbit and adnexal cysticercosis:
    • The extraocular muscles (superior rectus- most common) form is the most common type of orbital and adnexal cysticercosis.
    • Presents as periocular swelling, proptosis, ptosis, pain, diplopia, restriction of ocular motility, strabismus, decreased vision, lid edema and orbital cellulitis.
  • Ocular cysticercosis:
    • Intraocular cysticercosis can involve either the anterior or the posterior segment (more common).
    • Presents as blurring of vision, uveitis, vitritis, scotoma, and photopsia.

Diagnosis

B-scan Ultrasound: Diagnostic for intraocular cysticercosis; scolex within the cyst can be identified.

Serology: Detection of anti-cysticercus antibodies via ELISA.

Ophthalmic Examination: Identification of cysts in the AC or vitreous, signs of inflammation or retinal detachment.

Treatment

Ocular cysticercosis:

Surgical Treatment: Early removal of cysts via pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) or transscleral approach depending on cyst location.

Steroids: Systemic corticosteroids are used to control inflammation post-surgery.

Medical Management: Albendazole and corticosteroids are used for systemic infestation but with caution in intraocular cases to avoid severe inflammatory reactions caused by dying cysts.

A 45-year-old male presents with unilateral eye pain, photophobia, and redness for the past five days. Slit-lamp examination reveals circumcorneal injection, anterior chamber cells and flare, and posterior synechiae. Despite initial treatment with topical corticosteroids and cycloplegics, his symptoms persist, and intraocular pressure (IOP) is found to be elevated. Which of the following is the most likely complication of the condition he is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Complication

Description

Additional Details

Complicated Cataract

Common in iridocyclitis, characterized by posterior subcapsular opacities with "polychromatic luster" and "bread-crumb" appearance.
  • Matures faster with posterior synechiae presence.

Secondary Glaucoma

Can occur early or late due to iridocyclitis.
  • Early: Usually Open-angle. Blockage of trabecular meshwork by exudates/inflammatory cells.
  • Late: Usually Closed. Pupillary block causes impaired aqueous humor flow.

Cyclitic Membrane

Late complication where exudates behind the lens become organized in acute plastic iridocyclitis.

  

Choroiditis

Long-standing iridocyclitis can lead to choroiditis due to the continuity of the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.

  

Retinal Complications

Includes cystoid macular edema, macular scar/hole, epiretinal membrane, exudative retinal detachment, secondary periphlebitis retinae, retinal scars, sub-retinal fibrosis.

  

Papillitis

Inflammation of the optic disc, seen in severe cases of iridocyclitis.

  

Band-shaped Keratopathy

Common in children with Still’s disease and chronic uveitis.

  

Phthisis Bulbi

Final stage of chronic uveitis where the eye becomes soft, shrunken, and atrophic.
  • Without Shrinkage: Globe shape intact, vision loss, cataractous lens, retinal detachment, raised IOP early.
  • With Shrinkage: Lowered IOP, collapsed anterior chamber, shrunken eyeball.
  • With Disorganization: Significant eyeball reduction, scleral thickening, possible intraocular ossification.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Posterior uveitis?
questions.explanation:
Category

Examples

Infectious Causes

Viruses: CMV, HSV, herpes zoster, rubella, measles

Bacteria: Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Brucella spp., Borrelia burgdorferi, other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria

Fungi: Candida spp., Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces spp., Cryptococcus neoformans, Aspergillus spp.

Parasites: Toxoplasma gondii, Toxocara spp., Onchocerca volvulus, Acanthamoeba spp.

Non-Infectious Causes

Autoimmune: Behçet's disease, VKH syndrome, SLE, Wegener's granulomatosis, sympathetic ophthalmia

Malignancy: Intraocular lymphoma, malignant melanoma, leukemia

Unknown Etiology: Sarcoidosis, serpiginous choroiditis, Birdshot chorioretinopathy, retinal pigmented epitheliopathy

Type

Features

Symptoms

Defective Vision: Ranges from mild blurriness to severe vision loss

Photopsia: Flashes of light from retinal irritation

Floaters: Black spots or cobwebs due to vitreous debris

Metamorphopsia: Distorted vision, with straight lines appearing wavy

Scotoma: Blind spot or reduced vision area in the visual field

Signs

Vitreous Opacities: Fine or coarse opacities, "snowballs", or strands in the vitreous humor

Active Chorioretinal Lesions: Pale yellow or white, raised areas with blurred margins; possible retinal haziness and vasculitis 

Healed Chorioretinal Lesions: White, atrophic areas with choroidal thinning; black pigment clumping at edges

questions.text: What is the 1st line of treatment in a 35 year old patient presenting with Intermediate uveitis?
questions.explanation:
Step

Treatment

Details

1

Periocular & Systemic Steroids

Triamcinolone injection: 40 mg, 3 injections spaced 3 weeks apart.

Oral corticosteroids: Typically considered if periocular steroids are insufficient. Gradual tapering is done. (Option B)

2

Immunosuppressive Drugs

Agents: Cyclosporine, azathioprine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide.

Close monitoring due to potential side effects.

3

Cryotherapy/Indirect Laser Photocoagulation (Option D)

Cryotherapy: Controlled cold-induced injury. Used for snowbanking when less invasive treatments fail.

Laser photocoagulation: Focused light beam treatment.

4

Pars Plana Vitrectomy (Option A)

Surgery: For severe cases or complications (e.g., tractional retinal detachment). Removes vitreous gel, and clears debris.
